arXiv:2410.04642v1 [cs.LG] 06 Oct 2024

The Optimization Landscape of SGD
Across the Feature Learning Strength

Alexander Atanasov∗,1,2,4, Alexandru Meterez∗,2, James B Simon ,3,5, Cengiz Pehlevan2,4,6
1 Department of Physics, Harvard University
2 School of Engineering and Applied Science, Harvard University
3 Department of Physics, University of California, Berkeley
4 Center for Brain Science, Harvard University
5 Imbue
6 Kempner Institute, Harvard University
{atanasov,cpehlevan}@g.harvard.edu Joint first authorship, alphabetized
Abstract

We consider neural networks (NNs) where the final layer is down-scaled by a fixed hyperparameter γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. Recent work has identified γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ as controlling the strength of feature learning. As γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ increases, network evolution changes from “lazy” kernel dynamics to “rich” feature-learning dynamics, with a host of associated benefits including improved performance on common tasks. In this work, we conduct a thorough empirical investigation of the effect of scaling γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ across a variety of models and datasets in the online training setting. We first examine the interaction of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ with the learning rate η𝜂\etaitalic_η, identifying several scaling regimes in the γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-η𝜂\etaitalic_η plane which we explain theoretically using a simple model. We find that the optimal learning rate η∗superscript𝜂\eta^{*}italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT scales non-trivially with γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. In particular, η∗∝γ2proportional-tosuperscript𝜂superscript𝛾2\eta^{*}\propto\gamma^{2}italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∝ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT when γ≪1much-less-than𝛾1\gamma\ll 1italic_γ ≪ 1 and η∗∝γ2/Lproportional-tosuperscript𝜂superscript𝛾2𝐿\eta^{*}\propto\gamma^{2/L}italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∝ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 / italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT when γ≫1much-greater-than𝛾1\gamma\gg 1italic_γ ≫ 1 for a feed-forward network of depth L𝐿Litalic_L. Using this optimal learning rate scaling, we proceed with an empirical study of the under-explored “ultra-rich” γ≫1much-greater-than𝛾1\gamma\gg 1italic_γ ≫ 1 regime. We find that networks in this regime display characteristic loss curves, starting with a long plateau followed by a drop-off, sometimes followed by one or more additional staircase steps. We find networks of different large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ values optimize along similar trajectories up to a reparameterization of time. We further find that optimal online performance is often found at large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and could be missed if this hyperparameter is not tuned. Our findings indicate that analytical study of the large-γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ limit may yield useful insights into the dynamics of representation learning in performant models.

1 Introduction

The study of large-width limits of neural networks (NNs) has led to a variety of insights about deep learning. As network width N𝑁Nitalic_N tends to infinity, networks in either “PyTorch standard” parameterization or neural tangent kernel (NTK) parameterization converge to kernel methods Jacot et al. (2018); Lee et al. (2019); Sohl-Dickstein et al. (2020). Kernel methods have a fixed set of features, and networks in this kernel limit have fixed representations at each layer over training. By contrast, realistic neural networks adapt their features during the course of training Fort et al. (2020); Vyas et al. (2022); Lee et al. (2020). Feature learning is widely believed to be intimately connected to the excellent performance of NNs on practical tasks.

If one takes a centered NN111In this paper, we assume all networks are centered, meaning that f⁢(𝒙;𝜽)=0𝑓𝒙𝜽0f(\bm{x};\bm{\theta})=0italic_f ( bold_italic_x ; bold_italic_θ ) = 0 at initialization. This can be achieved by subtracting a non-trainable copy of the network at initialization. f⁢(𝒙;𝜽)𝑓𝒙𝜽f(\bm{x};\bm{\theta})italic_f ( bold_italic_x ; bold_italic_θ ) in NTK parameterization with inputs 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}bold_italic_x and parameters 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta}bold_italic_θ and scales the output as f~⁢(𝒙;𝜽)≡α⁢f⁢(𝒙;𝜽)~𝑓𝒙𝜽𝛼𝑓𝒙𝜽\tilde{f}(\bm{x};\bm{\theta})\equiv\alpha f(\bm{x};\bm{\theta})over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( bold_italic_x ; bold_italic_θ ) ≡ italic_α italic_f ( bold_italic_x ; bold_italic_θ ), one can control the degree to which the NN learns features. Taking α→∞→𝛼\alpha\to\inftyitalic_α → ∞ yields the “lazy limit,” where the network behaves as a kernel Chizat et al. (2019). By contrast, if one sets α=(γ⁢N)−1𝛼superscript𝛾𝑁1\alpha=(\gamma\sqrt{N})^{-1}italic_α = ( italic_γ square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for fixed γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and simultaneously scales the learning rate as η⁢N𝜂𝑁\eta Nitalic_η italic_N, one obtains a network whose hidden representations evolve even at infinite width (Geiger et al., 2020; Mei et al., 2018; Rotskoff & Vanden-Eijnden, 2018; Yang & Hu, 2021; Bordelon & Pehlevan, 2022), a scaling termed the “maximal update parameterization” or “μ𝜇\muitalic_μP” by Yang & Hu (2021). Although at practical widths and dataset scales, NNs in standard and NTK parameterization deviate from their infinite-width kernel limit Lee et al. (2020), networks in μ𝜇\muitalic_μP achieve their infinite width behavior at realistic scales Vyas et al. (2023a); Noci et al. (2024). Networks parameterized in μ𝜇\muitalic_μP generally achieve better performance, and μ𝜇\muitalic_μP can be utilized effectively for zero-shot hyperparameter transfer from small models to large Yang et al. (2021); Bordelon et al. (2023). The width does not affect the degree of feature learning in μ𝜇\muitalic_μP, so we identify γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ as the feature learning strength or richness parameter Woodworth et al. (2020).

This story leaves γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ as a free hyperparameter to be tuned, but despite its importance, little is practically known about the effects of varying γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. In this paper, we perform a thorough scaling analysis in which we train a variety of deep networks with γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ ranging across many orders of magnitude, with an eye towards both optimal tuning of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and cataloging the diverse dynamical phenomena that occur in different hyperparameter regimes. In addition to studying the lazy (γ≪1much-less-than𝛾1\gamma\ll 1italic_γ ≪ 1) and rich (γ∼1similar-to𝛾1\gamma\sim 1italic_γ ∼ 1) regimes, we pay particular attention to what we term the ultra-rich (γ≫1much-greater-than𝛾1\gamma\gg 1italic_γ ≫ 1) regime.

In this work, we focus on the online setting, where a fresh batch of data is given at each step and we train for a fixed time set by a compute budget. This is realistic of modern large-scale language and vision models and is scientifically clarifying, removing the confounding effect of finite dataset size.

Concretely our contributions are as follows. We systematically vary γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ over a suite of models spanning MLPs, CNNs, ResNets, and Vision Transformers (ViTs) on a variety of datasets. In all settings:

  • •

    Sweeping over both γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and the learning rate η𝜂\etaitalic_η, we observe a characteristic phase portrait of model performance in the γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-η𝜂\etaitalic_η plane, which depends only on the choice of the loss function and not the model architecture (Figure 1). We show that the optimal learning rate scales as η∗∼γ2similar-tosubscript𝜂superscript𝛾2\eta_{*}\sim\gamma^{2}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the lazy (γ≪1much-less-than𝛾1\gamma\ll 1italic_γ ≪ 1) regime and η∗∼γ2/Lsimilar-tosubscript𝜂superscript𝛾2𝐿\eta_{*}\sim\gamma^{2/L}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 / italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where L𝐿Litalic_L is the model depth, in the ultra-rich (γ≫1much-greater-than𝛾1\gamma\gg 1italic_γ ≫ 1) regime. Our phase portrait reveals an upper limit on γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ for a deep network to be optimizable for a given compute budget.

  • •

    After adopting the correct learning rate scaling, we find that large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ networks usually exceed or match the performance of naive γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1italic_γ = 1 networks if trained for sufficiently long (Figure 2). This disagrees with findings in the offline training setting Petrini et al. (2022), where strong feature learning was found to degrade performance.

  • •

    At small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, we observe the scaling of η𝜂\etaitalic_η with γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ predicted by kernel theory. To our knowledge, we are the first to observe that transformer-based architectures on large datasets can empirically reach the lazy limit. At slightly-too-large η𝜂\etaitalic_η in the lazy (γ≪1much-less-than𝛾1\gamma\ll 1italic_γ ≪ 1) regime, we observe the “catapult effect” of Lewkowycz et al. (2020) in which the loss quickly grows large before gradually converging. We see catapults for γ2≲η≲γless-than-or-similar-tosuperscript𝛾2𝜂less-than-or-similar-to𝛾\gamma^{2}\lesssim\eta\lesssim\gammaitalic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≲ italic_η ≲ italic_γ for cross-entropy loss, but only in a narrow band around η∼γ2similar-to𝜂superscript𝛾2\eta\sim\gamma^{2}italic_η ∼ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for MSE. Smaller γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ leads to larger catapults.

  • •

    At large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, we observe silent alignment as in Atanasov et al. (2022): at early times, the kernel aligns itself to the task before the loss drops. During this early period, NNs exhibit strikingly similar dynamics upon rescaling τ=η⁢t/γ𝜏𝜂𝑡𝛾\tau=\eta t/\gammaitalic_τ = italic_η italic_t / italic_γ, with the loss often exhibiting step-wise drops as in Saxe et al. (2014); Simon et al. (2023b) even in very realistic networks. We further observe that the loss drops at the end of silent alignment coincide with the Hessian growth predicted by the edge of stability (EOS; Cohen et al. (2021)).

  • •

    At optimal learning rate, we see a surprising agreement in the loss trajectories of large-γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ networks at late times in training. This suggests that large-γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ networks are learning similar features and functions past a certain threshold. We verify this similarity by comparing losses, accuracies, learned functions, and internal representations.

  • •

    Finally, we reproduce and analytically derive our phase portrait and many of the above behaviors in the simple setting of a linear neural network model (Section 4). There, we show the modified η𝜂\etaitalic_η scaling in the large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ regime is due to a progressive sharpening effect.

We review the catapult, silent alignment, and progressive sharpening effects in Appendix C.

1.1 Related Works

Chizat et al. (2019) introduced the laziness parameter α𝛼\alphaitalic_α in their seminal work. Mei et al. (2018); Rotskoff & Vanden-Eijnden (2018) introduced networks in mean-field parameterization. Geiger et al. (2020) introduced the correct scaling of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α with N𝑁Nitalic_N as α=(γ⁢N)−1𝛼superscript𝛾𝑁1\alpha=(\gamma\sqrt{N})^{-1}italic_α = ( italic_γ square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to achieve feature learning at infinite width. They also highlighted that γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ can be identified as the parameter that controls feature learning. Yang & Hu (2021) expanded this idea to deep networks of arbitrary architecture and coined the term μ𝜇\muitalic_μP. Bordelon & Pehlevan (2022) described this limit in terms of dynamical mean field theory. Extensions to infinite depth were performed in Bordelon et al. (2023) and Yang et al. (2023b) and to infinite attention in Bordelon et al. (2024c). We give a review of network parameterizations in Appendix B. A key motivation for this work is that γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is the main free parameter in the DMFT description of infinite-width feature learning networks, warranting a more thorough empirical investigation.

The question of optimal γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ was explored in the paper of Petrini et al. (2022). There, for several models in the offline setting, they showed large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ networks performed worse. In a linear network toy model, Pesme et al. (2021) showed that SGD noise could be absorbed into a rescaling of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. Sclocchi et al. (2023) performed a large set of thorough experiments to study the interplay between the SGD noise in different regimes of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and find that SGD noise can hurt or help in the offline setting. By contrast to these papers, we focus on the online setting. We comment on this further in Section 2.1. Under cross-entropy loss, Agarwala et al. (2020) performed extensive sweeps on un-centered networks over γ,η𝛾𝜂\gamma,\etaitalic_γ , italic_η, identifying γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ as the soft-max temperature, similarly finding that slightly larger γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ achieves top performance. Our cross-entropy results overlap with this work and recover their findings, but we additionally identify a different way to scale η𝜂\etaitalic_η at large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, allowing us to probe the very rich limits without training instability.

Various analytical studies of the large-γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ limit have been performed in the setting of linear networks Atanasov et al. (2022); Tu et al. (2024), with Jacot et al. (2021) terming this limit the “saddle-to-saddle” regime. The feature learning parameter has been shown to play a key role in the mechanism for grokking in Kumar et al. (2024). The paper of Kalra et al. (2023) performed a thorough analysis of the causes of progressive sharpening and catapult behavior in networks across μ𝜇\muitalic_μP and SP in the offline setting. In the online setting we show that all effects are present in μ𝜇\muitalic_μP and are modulated by the γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ parameter. In the setting of a linear network, Marion & Chizat (2024) also found a nontrivial and depth-dependent sharpening effect. Earlier works studying the effect of varying the γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ parameter Sclocchi et al. (2023); Bordelon & Pehlevan (2022; 2023) focused on the offline setting of training with repeated data until some convergence criterion is satisfied.

2 Setup and Notation

The loss of each batch is given by a mean of per-example losses:

(1)

We will consider both mean-squared-error and cross-entropy loss for ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. In this work we focus on optimizing the parameters by vanilla SGD, as even in this simple setting, the effect of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is not well-understood. For small batch sizes, the the SGD effects are controlled by the ratio η/B𝜂𝐵\eta/Bitalic_η / italic_B Jastrzebski et al. (2017); Smith et al. (2020); Sclocchi et al. (2023). We verify this this in Appendix H.

We study networks trained on the datasets, MNIST, CIFAR and TinyImageNet. Our motivation is to study networks training in the online setting over several orders of magnitude in time. To this end, we adopt larger versions of these datasets: “MNIST-1M” and CIFAR-5M, and apply strong data augmentation to TinyImagenet. We generate MNIST-1M using the denoising diffusion model Ho et al. (2020) in Pearce (2022). We use CIFAR-5M from Nakkiran et al. (2021). Earlier results in Refinetti et al. (2023) show that networks trained on CIFAR-5M have very similar trajectories to those trained on CIFAR-10 without repetition.

2.1 Why Train Online?

In the modern era of large models, the full training set is seldom repeated Kaplan et al. (2020); Muennighoff et al. (2023). Online, the effect of SGD noise was seen to have negligible effect on scaling both empirically Vyas et al. (2023b) and theoretically Paquette et al. (2024). The online setting thus allows us to isolate properties of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ as an optimization hyperparameter for the population gradient flow that SGD approximates. This removes the complicated overfitting effects that have been theoretically shown to build up when data is repeated Bordelon et al. (2024a), as well as the many regimes of SGD under an interpolation constraint Sclocchi & Wyart (2024).

3 Empirical Results

In this section we consider a variety of architectures: MLPs, CNNs, ResNet-18s, and Vision Transformers (ViTs), trained on a variety of tasks. We first discuss the different regimes observed in the η𝜂\etaitalic_η-γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ plane across architectures. We then discuss the properties of the Hessian, and identify specific dynamical phenomena. Finally, we focus on the large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ limit and show that learned functions learned representations largely agree across large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ networks.

3.1 Phase Portrait of η𝜂\etaitalic_η with γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ

We begin by considering the γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-η𝜂\etaitalic_η plane for a variety of architectures and datasets. We sweep jointly over every pair of η,γ𝜂𝛾\eta,\gammaitalic_η , italic_γ in a log-spaced grid running from γ=10−5𝛾superscript105\gamma=10^{-5}italic_γ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 105superscript10510^{5}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For each γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, we sweep from η=1012𝜂superscript1012\eta=10^{12}italic_η = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to η=10−12𝜂superscript1012\eta=10^{-12}italic_η = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 12 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT downwards in a log-spaced grid until the first convergent η𝜂\etaitalic_η is reached. After finding the first convergent η𝜂\etaitalic_η, we sweep over a range of η𝜂\etaitalic_η below it. We consider both MSE and cross-entropy losses. Further details are given in Appendix A.

At small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, η∝γ2proportional-to𝜂superscript𝛾2\eta\propto\gamma^{2}italic_η ∝ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for lazy networks

We consider the limit of small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, γ→0→𝛾0\gamma\to 0italic_γ → 0. This recovers the lazy limit of Chizat et al. (2019). The (empirical) neural tangent kernel of the network is KN⁢T⁢K≡∇f⋅∇f∼Θ⁢(γ−2)subscript𝐾𝑁𝑇𝐾⋅∇𝑓∇𝑓similar-toΘsuperscript𝛾2K_{NTK}\equiv\nabla f\cdot\nabla f\sim\Theta(\gamma^{-2})italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_T italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≡ ∇ italic_f ⋅ ∇ italic_f ∼ roman_Θ ( italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). In kernel regression under MSE loss, the maximum achievable learning rate is proportional to the top eigenvalue of the Hessian. This sets the upper bound to be η∼γ2similar-to𝜂superscript𝛾2\eta\sim\gamma^{2}italic_η ∼ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. More generally at small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ the Hessian is dominated by the Gauss-Newton term, as we will explicitly write in Section 3.2, equation 3. This term scales as Θ⁢(γ−2)Θsuperscript𝛾2\Theta(\gamma^{-2})roman_Θ ( italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Moreover, in order to achieve a trainable network as γ→0→𝛾0\gamma\to 0italic_γ → 0, one needs the loss to have a nonzero change in ℒℒ\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L in that limit. We have:

By centering, near initialization ℓ′superscriptℓ′\ell^{\prime}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is Θγ⁢(1)subscriptΘ𝛾1\Theta_{\gamma}(1)roman_Θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 ). The left hand side is thus Θ⁢(γ−2)Θsuperscript𝛾2\Theta(\gamma^{-2})roman_Θ ( italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), so the minimum learning rate to see the loss drop in T𝑇Titalic_T steps scales as η∼γ2/Tsimilar-to𝜂superscript𝛾2𝑇\eta\sim\gamma^{2}/Titalic_η ∼ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_T. We see this on the left region of the plots in Figure 1 and 1. We verify that networks of different but sufficiently small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ have the same loss dynamics in Appendix I.1, indicating that the lazy limit is reached by realistic networks.

At small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and larger η𝜂\etaitalic_η, catapults can occur

For η𝜂\etaitalic_η larger than the sharpness allowed by convex optimization, the loss explodes early on in time. For a range of η𝜂\etaitalic_η above this, the loss eventually drops again. This is the catapult effect of Lewkowycz et al. (2020). The maximal learning rate for these scales as γ2superscript𝛾2\gamma^{2}italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT under MSE loss and as γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ under cross-entropy loss. We revisit this in Section 3.3 and Figure 4.

At large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, there are two learning rate scalings

Empirically, in Figures 1 and 1, we observe a “triangle of optimizability” in the large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ limit. To our knowledge prior works have not highlighted this fact. The upper boundary of the maximal learning rate before the loss explodes is found empirically to scale as η∼γ2/Lsimilar-to𝜂superscript𝛾2𝐿\eta\sim\gamma^{2/L}italic_η ∼ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 / italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. On the other hand, at large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, activation movement precedes function movement, by contrast to the lazy limit. The minimal learning rate scaling in order for the activations to move by Θγ⁢(1)subscriptΘ𝛾1\Theta_{\gamma}(1)roman_Θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 ) is η∼γsimilar-to𝜂𝛾\eta\sim\gammaitalic_η ∼ italic_γ, as in Bordelon & Pehlevan (2022), or η∼γ/Tsimilar-to𝜂𝛾𝑇\eta\sim\gamma/Titalic_η ∼ italic_γ / italic_T under a budget of T𝑇Titalic_T training steps. Taking C∝T⁢Bproportional-to𝐶𝑇𝐵C\propto TBitalic_C ∝ italic_T italic_B to be the compute budget, we see that generally increasing C𝐶Citalic_C increases the optimizable region for large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ.

Sufficiently large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ NNs see improved scaling laws

We plot the loss in time across γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ in Figure 2. We overlay two different scaling curves as dashed lines. We see the slopes between the small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ lazy networks and the large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ rich networks appear substantively different. The former slope can be predicted from kernel theory, as in Pillaud-Vivien et al. (2018) and Bordelon & Pehlevan (2021). Increasing γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ beyond some threshold does not appear to improve the scaling law. This echoes similar findings as found by the recent model of Bordelon et al. (2024b).

Large-γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ NNs achieve good generalization, given sufficient training time

We plot the accuracy of NNs across γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ in Figure 2. We see that generalization improves with larger γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, eventually reaching a roughly constant value. This contrasts with studies in the offline setting Geiger et al. (2020); Sclocchi et al. (2023) where performance decreases at large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. We highlight that if networks do not train long enough, a non-monotonicity is indeed present, but this goes away with longer online training.

3.2 Hessian Scaling

We next consider the scaling of the Hessian of the loss as a function of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. (3)

Here, we have split the Hessian into a Gauss-Newton term 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G and a loss gradient term ℛℛ\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R. The Hessian contains important properties about the optimization landscape. One particularly important quantity is top eigenvalue λm⁢a⁢xsubscript𝜆𝑚𝑎𝑥\lambda_{max}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, also known as the sharpness. The sharpness governs the maximal allowable learning rate in a convex optimization problem.

Across all tasks we find remarkably consistent behavior of the Hessian spectrum, see Figure 3. For γ≪1much-less-than𝛾1\gamma\ll 1italic_γ ≪ 1, the network stays lazy and the Hessian does not evolve. There, the Hessian is dominated by the 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G term, which scales as γ−2superscript𝛾2\gamma^{-2}italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Once γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ exceeds a threshold however, we observe a distinct change in scaling at the end of training. For feed-forward MLPs and CNNs, we verify a scaling going as γ−2/Lsuperscript𝛾2𝐿\gamma^{-2/L}italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 / italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In section 4, we derive this scaling in a linear network model.

We also track how the top eigenvalues of the evolve in time in Figures 3, 3 and 3. For lazy networks we predictably see no evolution. In the next section we show that small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ but larger η𝜂\etaitalic_η networks can catapult and lower their sharpness. For rich networks we highlight that a very extensive number of eigenvalues grow to large scale. This is in contrast with the commonly observed phenomenon that for a C𝐶Citalic_C-class classification task there should be C𝐶Citalic_C outliers. Here, in the lazy limit there are indeed 10101010 distinct outliers, but in the rich regime there are no distinct outliers at late times.

3.3 Dynamical Phenomena

We here describe a catalog of different dynamical phenomena that we find in networks trained in the small- and large-γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ regimes. We give background on these effects in Appendix C.

The catapult effect at small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ

We see in Figure 4 that small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ networks exhibit large increases followed by decreases in the loss, with remarkably regular behavior, decreasing in scale as γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ grows. In Appendix D, we leverage a similar linear network model to arrive at the desired catapult scalings with γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ under both MSE and cross-entropy loss.

Silent alignment at large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ

We now consider the dynamics at large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. Empirically, we find that our sweeps do not detect any catapult effects once γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is large enough. Taking the optimal learning rate for SGD at large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ still yields a long loss plateau. During this plateau, the NN can be shown to be adapting its features, and appears to align its hidden-layer representations with the task. We illustrate this in Figure 4. This effect was identified in linear networks at small initialization in Atanasov et al. (2022), and shown to empirically hold in a restricted class of NNs on whitened data. Here, we show that it arises in a much broader class of realistic settings.

Stepwise loss drops at large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ

At very large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, we often observe loss trajectories following a characteristic staircase pattern, with one or more plateaus punctuated by sudden drops. This is a prediction of linear network theory Saxe et al. (2014); Simon et al. (2023a) that seems to hold even for very realistic models. We see these step-wise trajectories for MLPS in Figures 4, 27 and 35, CNNs in Figures 27 and 34 and ViTs in Figure 12. We show that, upon rescaling time as τ=η⁢t/γ𝜏𝜂𝑡𝛾\tau=\eta t/\gammaitalic_τ = italic_η italic_t / italic_γ, the early time dynamics coincide. The first loss drop goes as t∼γsimilar-to𝑡𝛾t\sim\gammaitalic_t ∼ italic_γ. We explain the origin of this timescale in Section 4.

Progressive sharpening at the end of silent alignment

Across all tasks and models, we find that the loss drop that ends silent alignment is always accompanied by a growth in the sharpness to the final value of approximately 2/η2𝜂2/\eta2 / italic_η. We show this in Figure 4. This is the large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ analogue of the progressive sharpening effect observed in Cohen et al. (2021). This effect is not present at small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ.

3.4 Comparing Learned Functions and Representations

Finally, we consider the question of to what extend different networks are learning the “same function” and the same representations. To this end, we consider two distinct networks A, and B as well as a held out set of test points. For each point 𝒙μsubscript𝒙𝜇\bm{x}_{\mu}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there is a correct class c𝑐citalic_c, so that [𝒚μ]c′=δc,c′subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝒚𝜇superscript𝑐′subscript𝛿𝑐superscript𝑐′[\bm{y}_{\mu}]_{c^{\prime}}=\delta_{c,c^{\prime}}[ bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a one-hot vector. We consider the value that a given network places on [𝒚μ]csubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝒚𝜇𝑐[\bm{y}_{\mu}]_{c}[ bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. On one axis, we plot network and on the other we plot network B. Networks are learning the same function if and only if this plot yields an exact diagonal line. In the lazy limit, we see in Figure 5 that indeed the two networks are learning nearly identical functions. We also see strong agreement between different network in the rich limit at the end of training. By contrast, rich and lazy networks do not have substantial function agreement.

We then consider the learned representations in Figure 5. Here, we plot a version of centered kernel alignment (CKA) between the final layer network activation kernel K𝐾Kitalic_K and the “task kernel” 𝒚⁢𝒚⊤𝒚superscript𝒚top\bm{y}\bm{y}^{\top}bold_italic_y bold_italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for 𝒚𝒚\bm{y}bold_italic_y a P×C𝑃𝐶P\times Citalic_P × italic_C class label matrix. We see that, after adopting a suitable time rescaling, the alignment scores for a variety of networks across γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ agree. Larger γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ networks retain slightly higher alignment scores.

4 A Simple Model Explaining Observed Scalings

In this section, we provide a theoretical model that explains all observed scaling relationships empirically observed in Figure 1 and analytically reproduces our phase portraits.

The following simple model will prove sufficient: a deep linear network of width one, trained on a single example. The network function in this case is f⁢(x)=wL⁢…⁢w1⁢x𝑓𝑥subscript𝑤𝐿…subscript𝑤1𝑥f(x)=w_{L}\dots w_{1}xitalic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT … italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x. We will initialize all weights to 1111 at initialization, and due to the commutativity of multiplication they will receive the same gradients and remain equal throughout training. We are thus justified in replacing all weights with a single weight w𝑤witalic_w and, letting x=1𝑥1x=1italic_x = 1, we need only keep track of the function value f=wL𝑓superscript𝑤𝐿f=w^{L}italic_f = italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.444 A technicality: because the variable w𝑤witalic_w is repeated L𝐿Litalic_L times, it will receive a gradient L𝐿Litalic_L times larger than one of the original variables wℓsubscript𝑤ℓw_{\ell}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To recover the original training dynamics, we would thus need to downscale η𝜂\etaitalic_η by a factor of L𝐿Litalic_L. However, because we assume L=Θ⁢(1)𝐿Θ1L=\Theta(1)italic_L = roman_Θ ( 1 ), we neglect this for simplicity and our γ,T𝛾𝑇\gamma,Titalic_γ , italic_T scalings will be unaffected. We divide the function value by γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and center it by subtracting off its value at initialization before passing it to the loss function.

We verify this in Figure 4, 5, and Appendix I.2.

Critical learning rate for the catapult effect: The above one-parameter model is sufficient to obtain all the coarse dynamical phenomena we see except for so-called loss “catapults.” As described by Lewkowycz et al. (2020), a network trained in the lazy regime with a just-too-large learning rate will grow quickly in loss, but then move to a flatter region of parameter space and converge.

The catapult effect generally requires two parameter dimensions to describe Damian et al. (2023), so our one-parameter model cannot capture it. In Appendix K, we describe and simulate a minimal two-parameter model that exhibits catapults. We find that for MSE loss, catapults occur in a narrow band ηcrit<η<ηmaxsubscript𝜂crit𝜂subscript𝜂\eta_{\text{crit}}<\eta<\eta_{\max}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT crit end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_η < italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with ηcrit∼γ2similar-tosubscript𝜂critsuperscript𝛾2\eta_{\text{crit}}\sim\gamma^{2}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT crit end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT just like ηmaxsubscript𝜂max\eta_{\text{max}}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

4.2 Scalings for Cross-Entropy Loss

All the above scalings are summarized in Table 1.

We perform simulations of our one-parameter model in a fashion analogous to our parameter sweeps for deep networks for T=103𝑇superscript103T=10^{3}italic_T = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT steps of gradient descent. The results, plotted in Figure 6, confirm our analytical scalings and match our phase portraits for deep networks (e.g. Figure 1).

5 Conclusion

We have presented a set of large-scale empirical sweeps across γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ for deep networks trained on realistic data. We have empirically identified how the upper bound for optimizable η𝜂\etaitalic_η is determined across a host of different γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ in terms of the training time and the depth of the network. We see that, conditional on an adjusted learning rate scaling with γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, larger γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ NNs are competitive with or better than γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1italic_γ = 1 NNs after training long enough. We have seen very predictable scaling of hessian spectra with γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and identified various dynamical phenomena whose appearance is governed by the size of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. By appeal to a linear NN, we have been able to explain many of our observed scalings. In future steps, we hope to to extend our analysis to optimizers beyond SGD.

Author Contributions

AA ran early empirics that revealed the phase plot structure, initiating the project, ran all MNIST-1M and most CIFAR-5M experiments, wrote the initial draft, offered feedback on the solvable model, and led the team logistically. AM ran all ViT experiments and experiments on TinyImageNet, helped with CIFAR-5M experiments, observed the role of attention temperature in the final phase diagram, and offered technical feedback on both experimental and theoretical fronts. JS proposed and developed the solvable model exhibiting all phases, ran empirics on that model, and offered technical feedback on all experiments. CP supervised the project and gave feedback and direction. All authors contributed substantially to the final draft.

Appendix A Experimental Details

We evaluate all our experiments on A100 and H100 GPUs, using PyTorch. In order to compute the Hessian eigenvalues we use PyHessian Yao et al. (2020) evaluated on 1111 fixed batch of size 512512512512 at every point in time. In the following subsections we provide individual experimental details for every model trained.

Across all models, we swept over γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ from 10−5superscript10510^{-5}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 105superscript10510^{5}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in a log-spacing with two samples per decade. We swept over η𝜂\etaitalic_η from 1010superscript101010^{10}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT down to a lower limit that varied by experiment, as reported on the plots. For each run that caused a gradient explosion, the model was not saved. We only saved models with η𝜂\etaitalic_η less than or equal to the first convergent learning rate for each value of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. For the MNIST-1M plots and CIFAR-5M plots, at each value of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ we only kept the seven values of η𝜂\etaitalic_η that are within a factor of 103superscript10310^{3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from the top stable η𝜂\etaitalic_η to make the plots as in e.g. Figure 1.

In all cases, we created a CenteredModel class, ensuring that the output of the network is zero at initialization by making the following definition for the trained function f~~𝑓\tilde{f}over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG:

f~⁢(𝒙,𝜽)≡1γ⁢[f⁢(𝒙,𝜽)−f⁢(𝒙,𝜽0)].~𝑓𝒙𝜽1𝛾delimited-[]𝑓𝒙𝜽𝑓𝒙subscript𝜽0\tilde{f}(\bm{x},\bm{\theta})\equiv\frac{1}{\gamma}\left[f(\bm{x},\bm{\theta})% -f(\bm{x},\bm{\theta}_{0})\right].over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_θ ) ≡ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG [ italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_θ ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] . (10)

Here, 𝜽0subscript𝜽0\bm{\theta}_{0}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the initial setting of the parameters, and is not trainable.

In the case of ViTs we compare training with QK-LayerNorm and QK-Norm in order to account for the attention logit temperature.

A.1 Comments on Numerical Stability in the Lazy Limit

Here we detail a ubiquitous problem that arose in the training of lazy neural networks at small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. To our knowledge, this problem has not been highlighted in the literature. At very small values of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, approximately 10−3superscript10310^{-3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the appropriate learning rate in the lazy limit scales as η∼γ2similar-to𝜂superscript𝛾2\eta\sim\gamma^{2}italic_η ∼ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This leads to weight updates on the order of 10−6superscript10610^{-6}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or less. Machine epsilon for float32 is near 10−7superscript10710^{-7}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 7 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Because the final output of the function involves the subtraction in equation 10, the weight updates matter in both relative and absolute magnitude. For this reason, we find that we needed to go to double precision to reliably obtain curves below γ=10−3𝛾superscript103\gamma=10^{-3}italic_γ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In practice, we find that a value of γ=10−3𝛾superscript103\gamma=10^{-3}italic_γ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or even 10−2superscript10210^{-2}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is essentially enough to reach the lazy limit in the online setting for essentially all tasks listed. See Appendix I.1 for a check of this.

We also highlight, that it is insufficient to simply zero out the last layer weights at initialization as a way to center the network. The lazy limit of a network with zero-initialized last layer weights yields the final-layer conjugate kernel or NNGP kernel. This kernel has very different properties from the NTK, especially in that its dimensionality scales as the width rather than the number of parameter of the network.

A.2 MNIST-1M

A diffusion model generated version of MNIST with 1 million images, which we will call MNIST-1M, was used to train these networks. We swept over a variety of widths, depths, batch sizes, and architectures. Each individual run took approximately 15 seconds on an A100 GPU. For each setting of width, depth, batch size, and architecture, we swept over the fine grid of γ,η𝛾𝜂\gamma,\etaitalic_γ , italic_η stated above. This led to 7 runs per value of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ or approximately 150150150150 runs total for each phase plot. Most runs were repeated over three initialization seeds, and key quantities, such as loss and accuracy, were seen to minimally vary over the initialization. This is expected in μ𝜇\muitalic_μP, by arguments of approximate initialization independence at sufficiently large widths as in Bordelon & Pehlevan (2023); Mei et al. (2019).

The architectures we used were MLPs of depths 2,3,42342,3,42 , 3 , 4 and a feed-forward CNN of depth 4444 consisting of two convolutional and two feed-forward layers.

The corresponding test set for this dataset is the original MNIST test set.

Although it is quite easy for most networks to get to near 100 percent accuracy in one pass through this dataset, we believe that it fills an important gap in the space of datasets. It provides a task that is fast enough to learn, allowing for quick iteration, yet avoiding repetitions of data so as to remain online. In the era of online training, it is useful to have simple but large-scale datasets in order to test theory against. We do not claim that this dataset is representative of realistic imagenet scale natural data, but it is encouraging that virtually all effects observed in the CIFAR-5M and tinyimagenet datasets are also present in this smaller setting.

We observe that training accuracy on MNIST-1M meaningfully transfers to the original MNIST, and there is no observed overfitting effect in the networks that we’ve trained.

A.3 CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-5M

We train on the full dataset of CIFAR-5M introduced in Nakkiran et al. (2021). This includes both the train set of 5 million images as well as the 1 million image test set, making for a total of 6 million images. We stay in the one pass setting. We also trained on CIFAR-10 with heavy data augmentation. We swept over width, depth, batch size, and architecture as above. In essentially all plots, we followed the same recipe for sweeping over γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ and η𝜂\etaitalic_η. For some of the ResNets and Vision transformers, larger sweeps were performed.

The architectures we used were feed-forward CNNs of depth 4444 as above, ResNets of varying depths as well as ResNet-18s, and Vision Transformers.

The corresponding test set for this dataset is the original CIFAR-10 test set.

A.4 TinyImageNet

In order to train on TinyImagenet in an online setting, we use random data augmentations: rotations and crops. All the experiments on this dataset have been run using batch size 128128128128. Individual architectural details are offered for every plot. We train all the models under μ⁢P𝜇𝑃\mu Pitalic_μ italic_P (or Depth-μ⁢P𝜇𝑃\mu Pitalic_μ italic_P where specified), using stochastic gradient descent (SGD).

Appendix B Review of NTK Parameterization and μ𝜇\muitalic_μ-Parameterization

For detailed discussion of μ𝜇\muitalic_μP more generally, see Yang & Hu (2021); Yang et al. (2021); Geiger et al. (2020); Bordelon & Pehlevan (2022). The aim of this section is conceptual clarity on the difference between NTK parameterization and μ𝜇\muitalic_μ-parameterization, as well as to give some degree of motivation of the latter. See also the recent accessible works of Yang et al. (2023a) and Chizat & Netrapalli (2023).

There are several equivalent ways of parameterizing NNs that will yield the same dynamics as μ𝜇\muitalic_μP. In what follows, we focus on a scalar-output feed-forward network for simplicity. The key distinction between NTK and μ𝜇\muitalic_μ parameterizations it that the hidden layer activations move ΘN⁢(1/N)subscriptΘ𝑁1𝑁\Theta_{N}(1/\sqrt{N})roman_Θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 / square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ) in the former and ΘN⁢(1)subscriptΘ𝑁1\Theta_{N}(1)roman_Θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 ). One can straightforwardly extend the argument to more general architectures.

Appendix C Review of Dynamical Phenomena

In this section we review the essential dynamical phenomena studied in prior literature that arise in various regions of the η𝜂\etaitalic_η-γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ plane studied

C.1 Catapult Effect

The original catapult effect was studied in Lewkowycz et al. (2020). There, in the NTK parameterization, it was observed that at large but finite width, taking the learning rate η𝜂\etaitalic_η slightly above the bound given by convex optimization theory 2/λm⁢a⁢x2subscript𝜆𝑚𝑎𝑥2/\lambda_{max}2 / italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT led to a regime where the sharpness of the loss monotonically decreased. Follow up work has observed that the sharpness itself can undergo catapult behavior Kalra & Barkeshli (2023); Kalra et al. (2023). In Bordelon & Pehlevan (2023) it was argued and shown that in μ𝜇\muitalic_μP, one can observe catapults even at infinite width.

C.2 Silent Alignment

In Atanasov et al. (2022), it was argued that linear neural networks trained on whitened data starting from small initialization undergo an alignment of their weights in the task-relevant direction before their function output scale has grown sufficiently. The kernel alignment thus grows well before a loss drop, indicating that even at a loss plateau, the NN has learned a meaningful representation of the data. The results were empirically tested on a relatively small class of more realistic tasks. Here, we extend the class of tasks, and observe silent alignment phenomena for nonlinear networks on realistic and anisotropic tasks.

C.3 Edge of Stability

In Cohen et al. (2021), in the setting of full-batch gradient descent, it was observed that the maximum hessian eigenvalue grew to the scale of 2/η2𝜂2/\eta2 / italic_η, where it stabilized. This effect was further studied in Damian et al. (2023). In the SGD setting, a similar effect persists, though the final sharpness is modified from the 2/η2𝜂2/\eta2 / italic_η limit to something that depends more holistically on the spectrum. See Agarwala et al. (2022) for a theoretical study and discussion in this setting.

Appendix D A Two-Parameter Model Recovering Catapult Scalings

In this appendix, we describe a two-parameter model which recovers our main phase portrait and — unlike the one-parameter model of Section 4 — exhibits true catapult behavior with just-too-large learning rates in the lazy regime. We will first give an analytical treatment, then conclude with simulations.

Our model and argument will be very similar to those used by Lewkowycz et al. (2020), but with a slightly different focus: rather than examining the effect of the width N𝑁Nitalic_N on catapult behavior, we study how the γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ parameter controls catapult behavior. When width and γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ are properly disentangled (that is, when one uses μ𝜇\muitalic_μP), the width of the network plays no role in determining catapults. Indeed, recent work Bordelon & Pehlevan (2023) has shown that deep networks can catapult even at infinite width. The catapult effect does not happen at large γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, so we will ultimately focus on small γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ.

We begin with a multi-parameter model which we will shortly simplify. We consider a two-layer linear network f⁢(𝒙)=𝑾2⁢𝑾1⁢𝒙𝑓𝒙subscript𝑾2subscript𝑾1𝒙f(\bm{x})=\bm{W}_{2}\bm{W}_{1}\bm{x}italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) = bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x with width N𝑁Nitalic_N trained on a single example 𝒙,𝐲𝒙𝐲\bm{x},\mathbf{y}bold_italic_x , bold_y. D.2 Cross-entropy loss

As with the one-parameter model of Section 4, we may also train our two-parameter model with the binary cross-entropy loss given in Equation 9. The dynamics for cross-entropy loss are substantially more difficult to analyze than those for MSE — in fact, as noted by Meng et al. (2024), even an ordinary linear model trained with cross-entropy loss will exhibit chaotic dynamic in certain parameter regimes! In actual fact, the dynamics are quite similar, scaling-wise, to those for MSE, except in a critical “catapult triangle” in the lazy regime in which ηcrit<η<ηmaxsubscript𝜂crit𝜂subscript𝜂max\eta_{\text{crit}}<\eta<\eta_{\text{max}}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT crit end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_η < italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ηcrit∼γ2similar-tosubscript𝜂critsuperscript𝛾2\eta_{\text{crit}}\sim\gamma^{2}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT crit end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ηmax∼γsimilar-tosubscript𝜂𝛾\eta_{\max}\sim\gammaitalic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_γ. Recall that our one-parameter model neither converged nor diverged in this regime. Our two-parameter model begins to show similar behavior, but, after sufficiently long training time, bounces to a different part of the loss landscape and converges. The dynamics here are similar to the catapult dynamics described by Damian et al. (2023), except that the “unstable direction” sees a straight-walled loss basin instead of a quadratic basin (think ℒ⁢(x)=|x|ℒ𝑥𝑥\mathcal{L}(x)=|x|caligraphic_L ( italic_x ) = | italic_x | instead of ℒ⁢(x)=x2ℒ𝑥superscript𝑥2\mathcal{L}(x)=x^{2}caligraphic_L ( italic_x ) = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). We anticipate an analytical treatment in the style of Damian et al. (2023) would be elucidating, but it could make up a substantial part of a paper in and of itself, so at this point we turn to numerics.

D.3 Simulations of the two-parameter toy model

We numerically simulate our two-parameter model for both loss functions considered. For MSE, we train for T=103𝑇superscript103T=10^{3}italic_T = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT steps. For cross-entropy, we train for T≈3×104𝑇3superscript104T\approx 3\times 10^{4}italic_T ≈ 3 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT steps to give the dynamics in the “catapult triangle” more time to converge.

The results are shown in Figures 8 and 9. We plot both the final loss and the maximum loss at any point in training. In both cases, we see phase portraits very similar to those for our one-parameter model (Figure 6), but we also see the loss exploding before convergence in the catapult phase.

Appendix F Effect of width and check of μ𝜇\muitalic_μ-consistency

In this section we provide checks of μ𝜇\muitalic_μP working. We do this by both plotting in Figure 13 and Figure 14 as well as their CNN and croseentropy analogues. We observe the following:

  • •

    The loss curves as a function of time across widths begin to match as N𝑁Nitalic_N grows, confirming that they are converging to an “infinite width” loss curve

  • •

    The performance vs the learning rate η𝜂\etaitalic_η across width is stable, as expected in μ𝜇\muitalic_μP.

Importantly, as a consequence of consistency across widths at sufficiently large N𝑁Nitalic_N, one does not need to additionally vary the width parameter in order to exhaustively sweep out the space of feature learning NNs.

Appendix H Effect of batch size

In this section, we verify that in the online limit, different batch sizes have a relatively negligible effect on the dynamics. The batch noise does however make it so that smaller batches cause higher variance in the loss. This is the tradeoff for being able to train to a lower loss at fixed dataset.

Appendix L Kernel-Target Alignment

In this section we define what we mean by kernel-target alignment. In the case of a single-class task with labels y𝑦yitalic_y for each 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}bold_italic_x, we consider a kernel associated to a kernel K𝐾Kitalic_K originating from an (initialized or trained) neural network. This can be either the neural tangent kernel, NTK⁢(𝒙,𝒙′)≡∇f⁢(𝒙)⋅∇f⁢(𝒙′)NTK𝒙superscript𝒙′⋅∇𝑓𝒙∇𝑓superscript𝒙′\mathrm{NTK}(\bm{x},\bm{x}^{\prime})\equiv\nabla f(\bm{x})\cdot\nabla f(\bm{x}% ^{\prime})roman_NTK ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≡ ∇ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) ⋅ ∇ italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), or the hidden layer kernel, Kℓ⁢(𝒙,𝒙′)≡ϕℓ⁢(𝒙)⋅ϕℓ⁢(𝒙′)superscript𝐾ℓ𝒙superscript𝒙′⋅superscriptitalic-ϕℓ𝒙superscriptitalic-ϕℓsuperscript𝒙′K^{\ell}(\bm{x},\bm{x}^{\prime})\equiv\phi^{\ell}(\bm{x})\cdot\phi^{\ell}(\bm{% x}^{\prime})italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≡ italic_ϕ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) ⋅ italic_ϕ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )). We evaluate P×P𝑃𝑃P\times Pitalic_P × italic_P kernel gram matrices K𝐾Kitalic_K on a held out test set of P𝑃Pitalic_P points. We stack the corresponding labels into a vector 𝒚∈ℝP𝒚superscriptℝ𝑃\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{P}bold_italic_y ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The associated kernel-target alignment is given by:

KTA⁢(K,𝒚)≡𝒚⊤⁢K⁢𝒚‖K‖⁢|𝒚|2.KTA𝐾𝒚superscript𝒚top𝐾𝒚norm𝐾superscript𝒚2\mathrm{KTA}(K,\bm{y})\equiv\frac{\bm{y}^{\top}K\bm{y}}{\|K\||\bm{y}|^{2}}.roman_KTA ( italic_K , bold_italic_y ) ≡ divide start_ARG bold_italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K bold_italic_y end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_K ∥ | bold_italic_y | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (19)

Here ‖K‖norm𝐾\|K\|∥ italic_K ∥ is some appropriate norm of the kernel matrix. There are many options, including Frobenius norm, operator norm (maximum singular value), and nuclear norm (sum of singular values). The alignment during the loss plateau is quite sensitive to the choice of norm on K𝐾Kitalic_K,. In practice, we’ve found that the nuclear norm produces the best results, with Frobenius and Operator norm metrics sometimes resulting in a dip of the alignment before the loss drop rather than a growth.

A related quantity, centered kernel alignment (CKA) Cortes et al. (2012), has been argued in Kornblith et al. (2019) to be a good candidate for the comparison of neural representations. In practice, we found direct CKA measures between NTKs of different networks to be very noisy and sensitive. CKA on hidden layer activations yielded more reliable plots.

  • You can use Alt+Y to toggle on and Alt+Shift+Y to toggle off accessible reporting links at each section.

Our team has already identified the following issues. We appreciate your time reviewing and reporting rendering errors we may not have found yet. Your efforts will help us improve the HTML versions for all readers, because disability should not be a barrier to accessing research. Thank you for your continued support in championing open access for all.

Have a free development cycle? Help support accessibility at arXiv! Our collaborators at LaTeXML maintain a list of packages that need conversion, and welcome developer contributions.
